title: Promoting gambling in the first degree
context: §712-1221 Promoting gambling in the first degree. (1) A person commits the offense of promoting gambling in the first degree if the person knowingly advances or profits from gambling activity by: (a) Engaging in bookmaking to the extent that the person receives or accepts in any seven-day period more than five bets totaling more than $500; (b) Receiving in connection with a lottery, or mutuel scheme or enterprise, money or written records from a person other than a player whose chances or plays are represented by such money or records; or &copy; Receiving or having become due and payable in connection with a lottery, mutuel, or other gambling scheme or enterprise, more than $1,000 in any seven-day period played in the scheme or enterprise. (2) Promoting gambling in the first degree is a class C felony. [L 1972, c 9, pt of §1; am L 1973, c 201, pt of §1; am L 1983, c 161, §1; am L 1987, c 83, §1; gen ch 1992] Revision Note In subsection (1)(a), &ldquo;or&rdquo; deleted pursuant to §23G-15. Case Notes Although it may have been error admitting into evidence, as expert opinion under HRE rule 702, officer&rsquo;s testimony concerning §712-1231(b), the social gambling defense, where defendant was not entitled to this defense in a prosecution for promoting gambling in the first degree under subsection (1)&copy;, error was harmless. 92 H. 98 (App.), 987 P.2d 996 (1999).
